description:
Murder of Crows invites you to be the first player to spell "murder" – but thankfully you don't have to use crow carcasses to do it.

Instead you're spelling the word with letter cards from your hand. Each player starts with five cards in hand, and on a turn a player either (a) draws two cards or (b) draws one card and plays one card. In addition to the Wild Crow card, which can do just about anything, cards come in five letters, each with a special power that takes place when you play that card:


    M – Misplace: Take one card from a player's murder – that is, his collection of cards on the table – and add it to your hand.
    U – Uncover: All players reveal their hands and you take any one card and add it to your hand.
    R – Reap: Draw one additional card.
    D – Drain: Choose one letter. All players discard one of those letters from play, if possible.
    E – Expel: Everyone discards their hand and draws three new cards.


When an opponent's card would affect you, you can discard a card of matching crow power – as indicated in the top left corner of the card – to be immune from the action.

From rulebook: "In this game you should be able to build the story of a life with the cards! There are four types of cards: Job and Career, Family and Everyday Life, Activities and Leisure and Sustainable Actions. The player who can make complete sets of at least three of the four sets of cards is the winner."

It's another popular game reimplementation from brazilian publisher Estrela. It is slightly based on original game theme but the final rules are completely different from original.

Box contents:

110 Cards
1 Rule book

---

Neste jogo você deverá conseguir construir a história de uma vida com as cartas! São quatro tipos de cartas: Profissão e Carreira, Cotidiano e Família, Atividades e Lazer e Ações Sustentáveis. O jogador que conseguir formular conjuntos completos de pelo menos três destes quatro conjuntos de cartas será o vencedor.

Conteúdo da caixa:

110 cartas
1 Manual de instruções

It was a small village at the base of the Black Forest in Germany.  Life was simple and peaceful in the village until a series of brutal murders.  The horrific nature of the killings left no question that werewolves had infiltrated the village. The villagers had little time to determine who the beasts were.  The werewolves were cunning, and used the paranoia to help the village tear itself apart.  Which side prevailed?

Black Forest is a cooperative board game for 3 to 5 players.  Players win or lose together as members of the village.  However, one player is secretly a werewolf, trying to defeat the other players.  In order to win, the villagers must ascertain which player is the werewolf, and eliminate all of his or her villager tokens in the Court House.

The game is divided into two phases.  In the Day Phase, players take turns placing their Villager tokens on village spaces (like the Fields, where they earn gold; the Market, where they can buy market cards; the Seer, where they can hire the Seer to have a vision on another player, and possibly gain clues about the player's role; or the Court House, where players vote to eliminate a Villager token belonging to one of the players).

In the Night Phase, players are dealt a hand of Night cards, and must choose one and pass the rest, until they have a card chosen for each player in the game.  Cards are then assigned and revealed.  The Night Phase is where the werewolf player tries to eliminate Villager tokens from the game, but also when the villagers try to fortify against werewolf attack.

After every other Night Phase, there is a Harvest, where the players must have enough gold to make it through.  If enough Villager tokens have been eliminated that the Harvest cannot be successful, the werewolf player wins.  Villagers can also win by upgrading all 12 Village tiles, but this involves spending gold that may be necessary for the Harvest.

Men Under Fire is a one-to-one scale miniatures wargame, using individually-mounted figures, vehicles, and heavy weapons. It is a tactical wargame, not a skirmish game. Players control as much as a full company of troops on the table, and maneuver squads and platoons as units. The game uses D6-based fast-playing rules, while still capturing the command challenges of keeping a squad or platoon moving forward under enemy fire.


    Complete rules, easy to read, with extensive diagrams, and design notes spread throughout the text which explain the reasoning behind the rules and give historical examples.
    The Just Another Mission system for generating historical forces for balanced one-on-one battle games.
    Unit organizations for the US Army, US Marine Corps, Great Britain, Germany, Japan, and the Soviet Union throughout World War II.
    Complete equipment lists for all of the above armies.

Spin-Tac-Toe combines Tic-Tac-Toe with a bit of luck. Instead of being able to mark a space directly you must use a spinner to decide if you can mark that square in the 3x3 field or not.

Each square has a half of the spinner circle colored red for "O" and blue for "X". On your turn, if you spin your color you can mark the square. If not, you can't.

The winner is the first to make a line of three. As in regular Tic-Tac-Toe it is possible for a tie.

This installment in the "Ratz-Fatz" series revolves around the horse farm. Like the other Ratz Fatz games, this is a small collection of several educational games for children (from ages 3-12). Game play revolves about recognizing the different gaits, equipment like saddle, bridle and reins,  and different types of horse food on the cards and making connections between them as fast as possible, another version of the game is a fairly straightforward memory game; other game ideas include storytelling elements, riddles, poems and rhymes.

Components: 3 wooden horses, 1 wooden donkey, 12 cards, 1 colour die, rules

It was announced as a remake of "Panzer Division Kommandeur" from Ad-Technos in 1985.

But, it is not a remake. From different designer, with different component, with different combat system, with different scenarios.
Actually, it is just a different game.

This version covers only the Eastern front in 1944.  This is another important difference.
One player must play a game as a German Panzer Division Kommandeur.  The other player controls the enemy Soviet army leader.

The game uses a random scenario creation system. The map area and each force are determined by dice.  The most important point that the goal of each army is given by randomly drawn chits.  There are 6 mission chits in the game and each player draw 2 of them secretly.  So, each player now know his goal and some information that his opponent might have.  The missions, are breakthrough, conquer, defense and so on.  Each mission gives each player victory points. At the end of the game, victory points are calculated for each player and compared to determine the winner.

components:
one map, one countersheet, one rulebook

Translated from the rules:

"Collect your carrots... but be aware of the angry farmer!"    
    
Players roll to advance on their own track. once they reach the crop field they roll another die, which allow them to look at 1 or 2 carrots or use the farmer to chase away another player back to their start field on their track.    
The first player to collect 3 carrots in his own colour wins the game.

This trivia game was released for the 60th aniversary of the Dutch theme park Efteling in 2012. The game contains 255 questions (most of them are multiple choice) in 5 different categories:

- Fairy tales
- Park's history
- Rides and attractions
- Shows and muic
- Interesting facts and figures

The game comes in tin box with a small game board (to determine the question categories) and score cards/tokens to keep track of  the score. The one wih the most positive scores when one player has a full score card, wins the game.

An educational game for children, focused on learning the numbers from 0-10. Like the other games in the Ratz Fatz series, this is a collection of games that can be played with the same material.

Central idea
A story or poem is being read, the kids listen, guess, rhyme and grab an object.

Components
10 wooden animals, 11 cards (showing a number one one side and the corresponding number of animals on the other side), one booklet with rules, stories, riddles and poems

Games that can be played:

1. Group and name: The players name the animals on the card and count them. Players are given different tasks (find a pet, all pets, a wild animal, the smallest, a black one, ...)

2. Sort by number: Cards are placed before/after another card according to the number of animals that are shown on it. The game can also be played with the number side.

3. Grab the animal: The animals or cards mentioned in one of the texts from the booklet have to be touched as quick as possible.

4. Memory game: Only six animals and/or cards are laid out on the table, the others stay in the box. When a number or animal is mentioned that is on the table, nothing happens. If one that is inside the box is mentioned, the players shout that word to gain one of the pieces from the table.

"Spies & Alibis is a Co-operative Mystery Game.

We are a team of Special Unit Detectives working together to discover which of the Suspects has taken the Government’s Top Secrets. We have to do this before the Spies board the Airplane and get away."
(from the game box)

Tiles are randomly selected and turned over by players to reveal "eye witness cards", each of which shows an enlarged part of a suspect's face.  The players must reveal enough tiles to properly rules out suspects and thereby deduce identity of the spies before the spies depart on the plane.  Each time a tile is turned over, there is a chance that it will be a "time flies card" which hastens the planes departure.  The game consists primarily of attempting to reveal as many eye witness cards as possible before revealing all 10 of the time flies cards, and then guessing as to the spies' identities.

Objective: Be the first moving up to field 132
- moving by turn -
throw the die and move according rolled number; ending on a red marked space follow instructions. Use 3 dice from out field '127';
remarks:
published ~ 1940's

Catholic Scattergories contains sixteen additional categories based on the Catholic faith!

How many Bible categories can you match before time runs out? Roll the letter die to determine the key letter for that round. You roll a "C". Now start the timer! How quickly can you think of a "Place Christ walked?..." Canaan!... "Things that separate us from each other?..." Carelessness!... Can't think of an answer? No problem. Just write down any answer that fits the category and you still score points if your answers are different from every other player. This game is entertaining, enhances faith and promotes learning.

Catholic edition and Bible edition use the same box. Catholic edition has a different barcode label attached.

Calling all Power Rangers! Lord Zedd has launched his assault. Its up to you to protect the planet by capturing Goldar, Squatt, Baboo, King Sphinx and the Putty Patrol.

Players play as their favorite Mighty Morphin Power Rangers on a gigantic plastic floor mat, as they spin the spinner and move around the board following the actions on the spaces where they land to protect the planet from evil Lord Zedd and his Evil Space Aliens!

Objective of the Game:
Be the first Power Ranger to collect four different bad guy disks and at least two Putty Patrol warriors to win the game!

Objective: play the game several times - each time you win you may wear the sticker 'Nick Knatterton'; player who was wearing this sticker most is the winner;
 - moving by turns -
roll the die and move forward; each space (of 25) shows information to follow (see cover inside); player who reaches field 25 (precisely) wins this game...
remarks:
published during 1960's

A ring toss game. Comes in a wooden box that has hinges on the front. The inside of the box has the instructions and more information about the game. The gamepieces are a wooden black man, a stand, a pipe and 4 red and black rubber rings.

The players toss rings and try to hook them on Sambos pipe which sticks out from the standup figure. The instructions are on the back of the figure.

From the box:

"For the school room or home by Mrs. F. L. Crown"

"A game in which fifty-six music symbols are quickly and easily learned and the habit of concentration, alertness and fair play is encouraged among boys and girls.

Music supervisors and music teachers will find 'Note-O' invaluable in the teaching of the names and definitions of music symbols.

Rules for playing 'Note-O':

The game of 'Note-O' contains forty players' cards, fifty-six dealer's cards and pasteboard discs with which to cover the symbols on the players' cards.

As many players may participate in the game of 'Note-O' as there are players' cards.  Each player is provided with a 'Note-O' card and enough discs to cover all the symbols on his card.

At the beginning of each game, a leader is chosen.  This leader is provided with the deck of dealer's cards and from it calls the symbols, one by one.  As a symbol is called, the player having that symbol covers it with a disc.  The process is repeated until some player has covered all the symbols on his card at which time he calls out 'NOTE-O.'  The first player calling 'NOTE-O', whose symbols have been covered correctly, wins the game.

The game may be varied by having any player announce 'Note-O' when he has covered three symbols in a row on his card.

At the end of each game, cards should be exchanged and the leader's cards shuffled before starting a new game.

The game is made much more difficult and more interesting when each player is provided with two or more 'Note-O' cards."

ReguÅ‚y Gry is fast, simple, card game licensed television station TVN7. It is based on the mechanism of exchange of cards and memory. ReguÅ‚y Gry is also a Polish television series production of all-star cast (Julia Kaminska, Maciej ZakoÅ›cielny, PaweÅ‚ Wilczak, Katarzyna Kwiatkowska and Jan Jankowski).

The goal is to get 5 tokens with images of the main characters from ReguÅ‚y Gry TV series. In turn, each player plays in front of him one of the four cards and must remember the name of this card. Then each player gives their cards to the left neighbor ang gains cards from the right neighbor (after that each player refills his hand up to 4 cards from the deck). Once the face-down in the stack to make the cards a player collects 4 cards with the image of the same characters from the show, to announce it. If he was right - achieved the first token. First collect five tokens wins the game.


ReguÅ‚y Gry to szybka, nieskomplikowana, karciana gra imprezowa na licencji stacji telewizyjnej TVN7. Oparta jest na mechanizmie wymiany kart  i zapamiÄ™tywaniu. ReguÅ‚y Gry to takÅ¼e polski serial produkcji telewizji TVN z gwiazdorskÄ… obsadÄ… (Julia KamiÅ„ska, Maciej ZakoÅ›cielny, PaweÅ‚ Wilczak, Katarzyna Kwiatkowska oraz Jan Jankowski).

Celem gry jest zdobycie 5 Å¼etonów z wizerunkami gÅ‚ównych bohaterów serialu. W turze kaÅ¼dy z graczy zagrywa przed siebie jednÄ… z 4 kart i powinien zapamiÄ™taÄ‡ jaka to karta. NastÄ™pnie podaje swoje karty sÄ…siadowi i otrzymuje nowe od drugiego z sÄ…siadów (dobiera do nich jednÄ… kartÄ™ z talii). Gdy tylko w zakrytym stosie do którego dokÅ‚ada karty, któryÅ› z graczy zbierze 4 karty z wizerunkiem tej samej postaci z serialu, ogÅ‚asza to. JeÅ›li nie pomyliÅ‚ siÄ™ - uzyskuje pierwszy Å¼eton. Kto pierwszy zbierze 5 Å¼etonów wygrywa grÄ™.

Will Thor survive the challenge of the trickster, Loki? Will the Valkyries overtake Odin?

In the oldest poem of Norse Mythology, the "Völuspá" tells the story of the endless struggle of powerful gods, dangerous creatures, and forgotten races. Which beings will dominate?

In Völuspá the game, the story will unfold differently each time, as a new force rises in dominance! Players take turns playing tiles with twelve different characters and creatures of Norse Mythology, using the power of these tiles to block, capture or intimidate in order to control other tiles and score points. The player who scores the most points by dominating other tiles wins the game.

Völuspá – a reimagining and retheming of the previously released game Kachina – is an easy-to-learn, tile-laying game that features great depth of play for 2 to 5 players. Völuspá includes the 25 tile expansion module "Saga of Edda", which offers even more strategic opportunities and replayability.

Golden Geek Abstract Game Nominee 2013

Kuddelmuddel - wie bei Hempels unterm Sofa
(german pun, means roughly translated chaos in the living room)

From the box back: Chaos is nice, chaos is fun. At least family Hempel thinks that. But who looks for something in the mess sweats...The colour die and the sample card show, which kind of thing has to be found in this mess. The players look up their cards quickly to find what is missing and who finds the most gets many things from the living room to his/her victory.

Contents: rulebook, 12 sample cards, 4 * 12 picture cards, colour die.

Gameplay: The cards are sorted into piles. 1 pile = sample cards. Then 4 piles which different card backs picture cards. Each child picks one picture card pile, means they have 12 cards now. Each sample card shows 6 pictures with a different coloured frame (example: boat, book, cup, telephone, plane, whale). The die is rolled. The colour rolled is the picture or the thing that the people are looking for. The first child playing his/her card with matching picture wins.

From the box:

"Code 3 Response! is the action oriented, strategy EMS trivia board game where you respond your ambulance along city streets to emergency scenes and transport your patients in a race to the hospital."

User Summary:

Game board is an overhead likeness of a city, with buildings, streets, hazards, and a hospital.  Players take turns moving their pieces according to rolling of die, and movement depends on negotiating map, hazards, and answering emergency procedure questions correctly.  Winner is the first to successfully negotiate all of this on the way to the hospital.  The game is intended as an educational aid for emergency training.

A Throwing game In which Players try to hit black humans with colored coins. Published in France.

The three figures are attached to the cardboard of the box. There are three cardboard disks that are used to throw at the figures. Each one of the figures has a minor slight crease in the neck area.

From the game box : Get the game ready by placing the subjects upright throw the quoits while standing at a distance od 10 feet from them. Each in turn, the players may get threee shots at the black persons and the game is played in 10 Times The player adds his points and puts the fallen pices right again for the following competitor.

(Your Name Here) and the Argonauts is single player game of adventures and legends set in Grecian mythology. You will take on the role of a hero set out to recover treasure, slay monsters, and find a place for yourself in the retelling of Greek myths. The game is played with a set of (initially) 30 cards that represent the monsters, treasures, and gods will become the tale of your adventure. This deck, and your character, will change and grow as you play more games, which is meant to reflect how tales become more embellished and outlandish each time they are told.

Each turn you flip over the top three cards of the adventure deck. These cards represent monsters, treasures, and the favors of the gods. You must then allocate your crew members to each of the cards. After all of your crew have their tasks, you roll against each card. The more crew members you have on a card, the likelier you are to resolve it positively. Monsters are defeated and treasures are won. Fail the roll and treasures will be lost to you, and monsters will send your crew members to Hades. As you are among the crew, once they have all died you will also be on your way to meet Charon.

Once the deck has been exhausted, the adventure is complete and you have won! The game is not over however. After each successful retelling of your adventures, the story grows! Much like tales become taller every time they are told, the adventure deck will become more legendary each time you win.

All of the cards in the game will have check boxes on them that will be used to represent the level of the card. Cards that were defeated or captured after a successful adventure will be marked: monsters will become stronger and treasures will lose durability. Some monsters will even bring reinforcements into your deck.

Additionally, so that the player may keep up, the player can also level up after successful adventures. This allows the player to start games with a larger crew and add new items to the deck.

This game from from Milton Bradley dates back to 1890 and features a lithograph map of an around the world race for two players. Each player in turn spins the spinner and moves the indicated number of spaces paying penalties for landing on an opponents playing piece. First player to circumnavigate the globe wins the game. There are safe areas where no penalty is called for if your opponent lands on your square.

The fourth Jerry Lewis-endorsed, big box (26" square) Hasbro game. From the same series that brought us High Stakes, Power Broker, and Spellbound.

Players compete to be the first to either collect $100,000 or be the only remaining player that has not claimed bankruptcy.

Players take turns rolling the dice and moving onto board spaces (called "blocks"). Certain blocks permit players to buy and sell seven different stocks. each stock type pays different dividends. Payment can be affected by Bull or Bear cards as well as Insider Informatin cards.

The sun rises on the solstice, and the tribes gather to the ancient battleground. Today, among these hallowed stones soaked with the blood of battles past, it shall be determined who shall rule the land in the year to come.
This is not the time for peace: it is the time for
RAGE!!!!!

A simple tactics game in which you control a group of barbarians, trying to wipe out all opposing barbarians on a battleground littered with druidic stones that can help or harm you. The main mechanic is the eponymous RAGE, which rises with the amount of damage your barbarians take, and makes them more powerful: of course if they take too much damage they still die.

Each barbarian is represented by a custom wood die, with a geomorphic cloth board styled after the designs of Elliot C. Evans.

Cracoviana takes you for the walk throgh Cracow old streets, where you find traces of historical events, rulers and artists. We learn about the city, its climate, history and tradition. Great way to make you children and grandchildren learn about the city, while having great time

Game goal is to gather as many "Wall Blanks" as possible in shortest time. Whoever achieves this and reaches Wawel, wins.
Players move through fields that symbolize streets of Old Town.

On street crossings there are questions from 10 sets - Legends, Artists, Tratition, Monuments, Events and so on, whic you must answer in order to get "City Blanks".

The birds are bothered by Carlo the cat! Who can help them to fly savely into the treetop and escape from Carlo? Schräge Vögel is a fresh game of chance, which trains motor skills.

Objective: Be the first flipping your cards into the treetop. Cards are taken & treetop is placed upon the table's centre; active player tries to flip a card into the treetop; in order to be flipped card is positioned that it sticks out of the table's edge. Depending where it drops player can add an additional card, take it back or even take more cards back to the own pile.

Murder! A body has been found in the idyllic woods of the Allgäu, one of Germany's most popular holiday areas. Side by side with commissioner Kluftinger (famous from a series of German crime novels), the players in Jagdrevier start their investigations to reveal the murderer. Each turn, the gamemaster places hints and clues in different places located in the Allgäu (e.g., Schloss Neuschwanstein). Each player travels from place to place, putting the clues together to deduce the murderer and his or her motive – but time is running and not every clue will contribute to the solution. Only the most quick-witted player can win this game!

Game description from the publisher:

Badou, Babar, and their friends want to use colored chalk to bring children into their jungle school – but alas, their friends have taken off running down the wrong roads. Can the players go after this motley army of youngsters and help them find the right path?

Based on the popular Japanese game show, TORE! is a game where 2 to 4 players compete against each other in challenges and quizzes to try to earn the most golden Pharaoh Statues and win the game.  The expansive board is built up as a three-dimensional play space representing the various chambers of the cursed temple from the TV show.

In this board game version, the players move together through five of the popular rooms of the TORE! Temple.  First they try to avoid being eaten by the stone monster in the "Stone Idol Chamber" then they must race to avoid being crushed by the closing walls in the "Wall Chamber".  After that, their task is to not get wrapped up in the "Mummy Chamber" before next trying to escape from the "Floor Chamber" where the ground slowly rises until the hapless player slides off to the their doom.  Finally, in the "Cliff Chamber", the players must use their wits as they are quizzed one-by-one while portions of the walls begin to protrude, threatening to push them over into the bottomless abyss.

Interspersed between these five rooms are additional challenges including quizzes, gambling to win more Golden Pharaohs, and even the ultra-popular "Spring of the Goddess" metal-ball challenge of trying to control and drop a ball into a goal using two ramp-like bars.

TORE! is a game of both chance and skill as your brain and ability to stay cool under pressure will help you as much as a lucky die roll. All the while the game maintains the same light-hearted humor from the TV show.

From the game rules (translated):
This game is a three-dimensional board game of trying to find the "Golden Pharaoh Statues" hidden in the cursed temple! Try to escape from the Pharaoh's many challenges while collecting more Pharaoh Statues than your opponents!

Timeline is a card game where each card depicts a historical event, invention or discovery on both sides, with the year in which that event occurred, invention or discovery was made on only one side. Players take turns placing a card from their hand in a row on the table. After placing the card, the player reveals the date on it. If the card was placed correctly with the date in chronological order with all other cards on the table, the card stays in place; otherwise the card is removed from play and the player takes another card from the deck.

The first player to get rid of all his cards by placing them correctly wins. If multiple players go out in the same round, then everyone else is eliminated from play and each of those players are dealt one more card for another round of play. If only one player has no cards after a bonus round, he wins; otherwise play continues until a single player goes out.

Game description from the publisher:

Samurai Sword is a game based on the proven Bang! mechanisms and set in feudal Japan. In this game, the familiar features of Bang! are enhanced by more dynamic and fast-paced game play, and thanks to a new scoring system – based on honor points and resilience points – there is no player elimination. Everybody gets to fight to the very end! Also, weapons and attacks are fused into a single card.

Greetings Semi-Intelligence: 221-B, and welcome to sentience. Upon completion of your training download, you will commence operation of Mining and Delivery Probe 4. Your task is to extract valuable materials from extrasolar planetoids and deliver the appropriate amounts of each to their target locations. It is imperative that these deliveries be made at any cost.

In the uncertain days leading up to the destructive Cataclysm of Earth, humans have settled other worlds and created robotic vessels to perform manual labor throughout their civilization. You will take on the role of one of these artificial intelligences tasked with mining asteroids for rare minerals and ice water, and delivering them to the colonies of humanity.

The goal of Ricochet Rock Jockeys is to retrieve goods from the Asteroid Fields between Earth and its colonies, and deliver them. You will explore the space surrounding Earth, mine asteroids, and make deliveries – all while vying for position with other players attempting to mine those same asteroids and make those same deliveries. Ricochet Rock Jockeys is an extremely fast-paced game of chance, delivery, and crashing spaceships.

Players start with a ship on Earth, then move that ship to explore, mine, and deliver mined goods. Players can bump into other players' ships, taking or losing goods based upon the strength of the impact. Players gain victory points for each successful delivery. Once the pool of victory points is exhausted, the player with the most VPs wins!

Collection of 6 boardgames based on the use of magnetic marbles (clickets) as game pieces.

The box contains six games. Each of the games is a combination of the nature of the magnetic marbles (e.g. magnetism) and strategic or random placement of the marbles on the board.

The object is to place or remove those magnetic marbles without moving or disturbing the marbles still occupying holes on the gamebord.

CLACTO HARLEQUIN is a game of dice, not unlike the traditional game, but combined with the magnetic force of the 'clickets' the game gets a somewhat wider perspective. Apart from the placement of the clickets of the board as the throw of the dice indicates, the players have tot take the magnetism in account.

The same principle goes for CLACTO DICE.

CLACTO FISH is about removing clickets from the gameboard without disturbing the other clickets.

CLACTO 4 AND 4, CLACTO TACTIC and CLACTO SNAKES all have the placement of clickets on the board as subject, without moving or disturbing the clickets allready placed.

A mathematical card game. The cards feature somewhere interesting in Sunderland, which is in the northeast of England.

Each card has a number between 0 and 9, except for the Double cards. Each player gets 6 cards and must look to see if a pair can be formed. A pair is made up of two numbers that, when multiplied together, make a total that is also on one of the two cards. For instance, you play a 5 and an 8 which makes 40. Thus the number 40 must also be on one of the two cards played. If successful, a pair is formed and can be laid face-up in front of the player. The first player to lay three pairs (6 cards) wins the round.

When a round is one, the other players add up the value of the cards in their hand and that is their score. After 12 rounds, the lowest score is the winner.

There are special rules for the Double Cards which you need to play because if you are caught with them in your hand when a player goes out, you get a nasty negative score.

This is an expanded game (but more subtle and a better design of the cards) that first appeared as Multitu in the 1960's.

In a foreboding castle somewhere in central Europe, a strange fear has descended upon the inhabitants.  One morning the body of a young girl was found, as pale as a sheet of paper, dry and totally drained of blood.  Vampires are on the prowl!  Who is the monster who murders innocent during the night?  Before the truth will be discovered, more than one person may face unjust accusations thrown out by the devious servants of darkness.  Will the vampires be successfully caught before they endanger the entire society, or will the castle and city fall forever into darkness?

Three characters in the castle are vampires. A human investigator is trying to determine which three of nine characters he encounters are, in fact, monsters hiding in human form so that he can eliminate them. The head vampire, on the other hand, must bluff cleverly, present confusing clues, and trick the humans into attacking innocent citizens. By doing this, the vampire can kill the most important characters in the city or conquer the castle.

Vampire Empire is a two-player card game with a lot of bluffing and player interaction.  In this very thematic setting, each player possess a unique deck of cards granting different powers, and each player had different goals to win the game!

Far in the future, war has been relegated to a spectator sport. As humanity has spread throughout the solar system, advances in material sciences have left us wanting for nothing yet craving new forms of entertainment.

3D printers ranging in size from minuscule to mammoth process material known as Nano-Goo (or just “Goo”) into virtually anything a person could need, from food and clothing to massive, space-faring ships.  Using these technologies, a few enterprising individuals capitalized on humanity’s need for entertainment and have brought back to life the ancient custom of gladiatorial combat -- done safely by remotely operating (teleoperating) vastly powerful machines of war known as War Bots.

Large 3D printing structures are dropped onto remote asteroids and other small, celestial bodies. These come with a small complement of devices which begin to process the raw materials of these asteroids into Goo, which these massive printers can use to create War Bots. Printers use a series of programs called .WAR Files, which give them the specifics of War Bots which they can then use Goo to print.

War Bots are printed out of Goo, which is programmed to take a specific form with specific functions. Because they are made of self organizing nanomaterials, War Bots can be modified by simple programs called .UPGrade Files – or upgrades. These upgrades can be applied to War Bots while they are in the field.

Governed by a strict set of rules, and limited by the programs made available to them, contestants manufacture and then fight with these giant machines, for the delight of audiences throughout the Solar System.

Upgrade Wars is a deck building, tactical combat game. Players begin the game with a starter deck of 10 resources and two War Bots (the giant robots that do the actual fighting).

Through the course of the game, they may purchase new programs to deploy as War Bots or to Upgrade existing War Bots that have already been deployed.

The battle field is divided into three zones - the Printer zone (where the magic happens), the Defensive Ring and the Front Line - a zone shared by all players.

Your bots traverse the battlefield under your command in an attempt to reach other player's printers and destroy them.

Complete Victory: The last player with a Printer still capable of creating War Bots wins the game!
Tactical Victory: Each enemy War Bot you destroy is worth 1 Victory Point. Each enemy Printer is worth 5 Victory Points. Once three card piles are depleted, the player with the most Victory Points wins!

Featuring strategic and tactical play - players must decide where and when to spend their resources, which can go to either purchasing new program files or deploying War Bots into the field of battle. At the same time, you must manage your existing War Bots to defend your Printer and attack the enemy.

Axia — a land with a glorious past, a most uncertain present, and an even more unpredictable future. Populated by what has been described as a fervent and warm-blooded people, Axia is in crisis – economic, social, and political: the longest-running recession in its modern history, the highest inequality in years, and a political system teetering on the brink of collapse.

In more ways than one, Axia is fighting against itself. Old divisions of the past have given way to new ones, and this generation – along with the next ones – has the most to lose.

Will you, along with your fellow industrialists, do your part to help Axia? Will you sacrifice short-term gain in the present for a brighter future? Can you do that, and survive? Perhaps you can, and perhaps you can even thrive – and you will, if you see opportunity where others only see crisis!

CRISIS is a turn-based game for 1-5 players who assume the role of business leaders, trying to rebuild their businesses and create value at a particularly challenging time. By skillfully placing their managers in a position to invest in companies, trade resources, and navigate the local bureaucracy and regulations, they can thrive and prosper in a time when others might struggle and decline.

In this trivia game, on your turn you will answer your question with 1 to 3 possible answers. The other players then vote using their cards whether the correct answer is #1, #2, #3, or "None of the Above." The active player gets 3-5 points if he's right, more points if he wrote fewer answers. The other players get 2 points if they guess correctly.

If players don't feel they can accurately guess, they can "cheat." They can look at the answer, get only 1 point that round, and must include the correct answer in the three they write on the board.

The game can be played by 2 to 6 players. Goal of the game is to collect 6 Heineken stars as fast as possible. You collect a star by answering a question card right. The questions are about the history of the beer and about Heineken. That's how players learn about Heineken. The board is a worldmap. This is how players travel from continent to continent. To illustrate what kind of export product Heineken is. Heineken the game is educative, enervating and fast played!

Year around soccer fun:

Comes with a game board, a set of dice,30 each of the following: Penalty Cards, Penalty Kick Cards and Corner Kick Cards

Object: Player with highest score wins

Designed for 2-4 players

Ages 4 and up

Players can lose the ball by landing on a pass blockers square, landing on a ball out of play square
landing on an offside square or by the results of a penalty card

Scoring Points can be accumulated by going completely around the board for 1 point or as a result of corner kicks or penalty kicks

First player to reach 20 points wins the game

Step inside a classic video arcade side-scrolling space shooter. Earth is once again at the mercy of on-coming waves of alien attack ships. Luckily, you have the one vessel that can defend the earth from the onslaught. Equipped with your all-important blaster, destroy wave after wave of alien ships and defeat the "Boss" at the end of each level, until the earth is once again safe.

Each Level of Blaster Waves is made up of a "Waves Round" and a "Boss Round". In a Waves Round, the dual-use cards in the main deck are used to setup waves of aliens attacking the player's ship, and also give the player a hand of cards for blasting away at those aliens. The blaster value on the card played from the player's hand is used to remove aliens in the attacking waves. Once the waves have been dispatched, the Boss Round starts where the player has a back-and-forth match with the Boss alien – with the Boss taking an action based on a reveal "Boss Action" card, and the player responding. If the player is able to defeat the Boss, the next Level begins. The player wins the game after defeating the Boss on Level 5.

The game includes Health indicators and PowerUps, such as shields, missiles, bombs, Health improvements, and even a "Wingman".

Trick Taking game for 4 players using the standard 52-card deck. Each player tries to take three tricks to get a maximum score. 
For 0,1,2,3,4,5,6,... tricks, the score will be  -5,1,4,9,-4,-5,-6,... points are awarded, respectively.

As you can see, at least one player is to get 4 or more tricks, thus getting a negative points.

Three tricks is a simple fun game invented by Jun Kusaba (Zyun Kusaba).

Two players have shaped pieces with varied numbering. The player rolls special dice then, according to the visible faces, groups them together to form a coherent logical order or sequence on the gameboard, eg:  "3-s": "a vertical box" "2 squares horizontal" etc. for score points.

The goal is to reach St. Jacques de Compostela in the way that collected the necessary assets: generosity, courage, resourcefulness, knowledge etc.

Basically the game is a race from Assisi to Compostela, witt rolling the dice, but with hazards on the way and rewards for virtues such as 'courage' 'generosity' and 'knowledge'.

Who reaches the finish first is the winner.

The object of the game depends of the hero played by the child:
Peter Pan: save as many children or remove hook
Hook: capture a maximum number of children or remove Peter Pan

Each player will move one checker according to the illustration of the card he plays.
Depending on the clan he represents, he will try to bring this character of his hero or away from each other. It must reflect the specific character displacement (2, 4 or 8 possible directions, the right to capture another character or not).

To retrieve a child captured, only the Duel is possible only once per player per game. We then use all the cards of two players to do battle. When all cards have been played, the one possessing the highest number wins the Duel and the child may choose to switch sides.

The game ends when one of the following events:

     Peter Pan is captured
     Hook is captured
     All the lost children are out of the game (as they were captured or saved)

Using the standard deck of cards, each player tries to have the fewest number of cards at the end of the game. All cards are spread out face-down in the middle of the game like the shape of "pig tail". Everyone starts with no cards in his/her hand. In your turn, you either flip a card or play a card from your hand. If it is different color and different number form the previous one, then it stays there. Otherwise you take all the face-up cards to your hand. The game is over when there is no face-down card in the middle of the table.

There are a lot of games with similar rules. This one is particularly strategic. As there are only 2 colors (black and red), you really want to time when you start decreasing the hand size. It is all about timing.

The game is strongly recommended for even number of players like 4 or 6. The game is nearly as good with 3 or 5.

Parity is a trick taking game using the standard deck of cards. You get the number of points equal to the number of tricks you take. However, if the number of trick is odd, then your score is negative. Thus, for 0,1,2,3,4,5,... tricks, you get 0,-1,2,-3,4,-5,... points, respectively. Since there are 13 tricks, someone must have a negative score!

"Toulon, 1793" is an operational level wargame covering the siege of Toulon, in the South of France, between 25 August and 21 December, 1793. It’s an area based system covering the entire campaign from the initial landing by Anglo-Spanish forces (at the invitation of the rebel Toulonnais) through to their evacuation of the town as their ships came under threat from the batteries of the previously unknown Napoleon Bonaparte.

Operation points are at the heart of the system and combined with an innovative combat, loss and movement system generate a vast number of decision points for the players. Chrome comes in the form of spies, gendarmes, multi-national forces (and associated cooperation issues), reconnaissance, variable reinforcements and much more. The game covers an area from Ollioules in the West to Sollies in the East and from Mount Farron in the North to Cap Cepet in the South.
